name: ENERGY STAR Res. GSHP (FS)

market_entry_year_source.notes: Assume historical penetration is captured in baseline

energy_efficiency_source.notes: 2022 ENERGY STAR v3.2 performance level residential ground-source heat pumps; COP = EER/3.41214

source_data.title: Updated Buildings Sector Appliance and Equipment Costs and Efficiencies

installed_cost_source.notes: Total installed cost is average of low and high total installed costs for ENERGY STAR v3.2 GSHPs in 2022; for existing buildings, added service costs of $1K for natural gas and $2K for distillate/other assigned based on EIA report, and added costs of $3K for new circuit breaker panel based on Redwood Energy report.

source_data.title: Updated Buildings Sector Appliance and Equipment Costs and Efficiencies
Residential End Uses: Area 2: Incremental Installed Costs for Efficiency Upgrades
A Pocket Guide to All-Electric Retrofits of Single-Family Homes
source_data.author: Sean Armstrong, Emily Higbee, Dylan Anderson, Diane Bailey, Tom Kabat

product_lifetime_source.notes: Average of low and high average lifetime values for GSHPs in 2022, rounded down from 14.5

source_data.title: Updated Buildings Sector Appliance and Equipment Costs and Efficiencies

market_scaling_fractions_source.heating: Applies to all residential fuel-fired heating; no electric heating is switched by this ECM

cooling.title: RECS 2020 Microdata
cooling.fraction_derivation: Central AC multiple of 59.5% was determined as a proportion of total homes with a ducted cooling system where heating is done using any non-electric heating energy source. Total homes with ducted cooling (main air conditioning equipment type = central AC = 1) in the sample is 12,211 homes, and then filtered for homes with non-electric heating system (Main space heating fuel != electricity = 5) 12,211-3,949 homes.

_description: ENERGY STAR v3.2 residential closed loop ground source heat pump in 2022, switching from other heating fuels
